description: From Middle English redel, redels, from Old English r«£dels, r«£delse (‚Äúcounsel, opinion, imagination, riddle‚Äù), from Proto-West Germanic *rƒÅdislƒ´ (‚Äúcounsel, conjecture‚Äù). Analyzable as rede (‚Äúadvice‚Äù) +‚Äé -le. Akin to Old English r«£dan (‚Äúto read, advise, interpret‚Äù).

entries.meaning: A verbal puzzle, mystery, or other problem of an intellectual nature.
examples: Here's a riddle: It's black, and white, and red all over. What is it?

entries.meaning: An ancient verbal, poetic, or literary form, in which, rather than a rhyme scheme, there are parallel opposing expressions with a hidden meaning.

verbs.description: riddle (third-person singular simple present riddles, present participle riddling, simple past and past participle riddled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To solve, answer, or explicate a riddle or question.

description: From Middle English riddil, ridelle (‚Äúsieve‚Äù), from Old English hriddel (‚Äúsieve‚Äù), alteration of earlier hridder, hrƒ´der, from Proto-West Germanic *hrƒ´drƒÅ, from Proto-Germanic *hrƒ´drƒÖ, *hrƒ´dr«≠ (‚Äúsieve‚Äù), from Proto-Germanic *hrid- (‚Äúto shake‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *krey-. Akin to German Reiter (‚Äúsieve‚Äù), Old Norse hreinn (‚Äúpure, clean‚Äù), Old High German hreini (‚Äúpure, clean‚Äù), Gothic êå∑êçÇêå∞êåπêåΩêçÉ (hrains, ‚Äúclean, pure‚Äù). More at rinse.

entries.meaning: A sieve with coarse meshes, usually of wire, for separating coarser materials from finer, as chaff from grain, cinders from ashes, or gravel from sand.
A board with a row of pins, set zigzag, between which wire is drawn to straighten it.

verbs.description: riddle (third-person singular simple present riddles, present participle riddling, simple past and past participle riddled)

entries.meaning: To put something through a riddle or sieve; to sieve; to sift.
examples: You have to riddle the gravel before you lay it on the road.

entries.meaning: To fill with holes like a riddle.
examples: The shots from his gun began to riddle the targets.

entries.meaning: To fill or spread throughout; to pervade.
examples: Your argument is riddled with errors.

description: From Middle English riddel, ridel, redel, rudel, from Old French ridel ("a plaited stuff; curtain"; > Medieval Latin ridellus), from rider (‚Äúto wrinkle‚Äù), from Old High German rƒ´dan (‚Äúto turn; wrap; twist; wrinkle‚Äù). More at writhe. Doublet of rideau.

entries.meaning: (religious) One of the pair of curtains enclosing an altar on the north and south.

description: From Middle English ridlen, from the noun (see above).

verbs.description: riddle (third-person singular simple present riddles, present participle riddling, simple past and past participle riddled)
